* Recap last week - html provides a common structure to documents. - example - html's structure is based on tags that wrap your content. the tags provide semantic meaning. * We installed some things - Sublime Text, our text editor - Front end snippets. A snippet library for common html, css and js tasks. - A basic CI-Template to work on in class. * Learning how a user interface is constructed will make you a better designer. - Why? - Design deliverables (visuals, wires, prototypes) go through a process of translation. An important part of honing your craft is designing for that translation. - How?

Naming

The single most practical skill for you to develop as a designer.

There are only two things in the world: nothing and semantics. Werner Erhard
There are only two hard problems in Computer Science: cache invalidation and naming things. Phil Karlton
Craft: Be deliberate when naming things. Be strict about the consistent use of naming from concept through production.

Every name introduced into a design or into a codebase is a positive or negative contribution.Names are not neutral

How to be effective at naming things. 1. Research the names you choose and make sure the words support the intended meaning as clearly as possible.

Example: These are html's radio buttons

One Two Three
How to be effective at naming things. 2. Name everything.

Cause if you liked it then you should have put a name on it.
